docs.lead_paragraph: I knew immediately that I wanted to be an obstetrician-gynecologist. As a medical student on my second night on call in labor and delivery, I pestered the attending doctors to let me deliver a baby, and six hours later I got my chance. With the guidance of a senior doctor, a plump, slippery, wriggling baby appeared in my hands. My adrenaline ran so fast that my hands shook when I clamped and cut the cord. I passed the infant to the pediatricians and was hooked.
docs.snippet: In the last decade, the number of medical students entering obstetrics-gynecology has plummeted.

docs.lead_paragraph: Hospital workers are often quick to put a urinary catheter in, but they can be much slower about taking it out. The devices, sometimes concealed by sheets, are easily forgotten -- sometimes until a patient is about to be discharged -- and the result often is an infection. Now researchers say they have come up with a reminder system that makes it harder for this to happen. Writing in the August issue of The Journal on Quality and Patient Safety, they say they have been able to reduce the length of use by placing stickers on patients' charts requiring doctors to reauthorize the catheter.

headline.main: A Detail to Remember About That Catheter

docs.snippet: Researchers say they have come up with a reminder system that makes it harder for hospital workers to leave a urinary catheter in too long.

docs.lead_paragraph: After a year of debate over whether antidepressant drugs increase the risk of suicide, a new study finds that a standard brand of talk therapy may offer the best chance to save those at the highest risk of taking their own lives. The therapy cut almost by half the risk of suicide attempts in extremely suicidal patients, many of whom were already taking drugs for depression, the researchers found.

headline.main: Talk Therapy Succeeds In Reducing Suicide Risk

docs.snippet: A new study finds that a standard brand of talk therapy may offer the best chance to save those at the highest risk of taking their own lives.

docs.lead_paragraph: Many people have asked me why my knees were hobbled by arthritis long before I turned 60. Being born bowlegged gave them a start. But I made things worse by jogging daily for about 10 years and playing singles tennis for an hour nearly every day for more years than I can remember until increasing knee pain forced me to cut back to three or four times a week. Still, in winter, I went ice-skating most days, and during the warmer months, I cycled 10 miles nearly every morning. About the only activity that did not damage my knees was lap swimming, which I did four or five times a week.

headline.main: Fit Is One Thing; Obsessive Exercise Is Another

docs.snippet: For the obligatory exerciser, exercise becomes a top priority, even more important than work, school, friends and family.

docs.lead_paragraph: The nation is in the grip of what looks like a terrifying melanoma epidemic: melanoma is being diagnosed at more than double the rate it was in 1986, increasing faster than any other major cancer. But why the numbers are increasing is a contentious subject, so touchy that one dermatologist called it ''the third rail of dermatology.''

headline.main: Melanoma Is Epidemic. Or Is It?

docs.snippet: Experts don't agree on whether an increase in melanoma cases means it is becoming more common or that more people are getting screened for skin cancer.

multimedia.credit: Gina Kolata of The Times discusses a new study that questions the benefits of melanoma screening programs.
multimedia.caption: Health Minute: Skin Cancer Screenings

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: Gina Kolata of The Times discusses a new study that questions the benefits of melanoma screening programs.

docs.lead_paragraph: I recently spent a few days recovering from having my appendix removed. As I padded around my house in my pajamas, I pondered that dear departed bit of my gut. I only became aware of my appendix when it flared with infection. Soon I was lying in an ambulance, with a paramedic poking at my abdomen. ''Oh yeah,'' he said, and went back to filling out paperwork.
docs.snippet: An appendectomy is the cause for pondering an organ with an inscrutable purpose, or maybe none at all.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE CLAIM -- Fight off a shark by punching it in the nose. THE FACTS -- Forget for a moment that the odds of being attacked by a shark at the beach are minuscule. Now imagine a dip in the ocean this summer turning into a tense encounter with a great white, its massive head within arm's reach and powerful jaws closing in. Do you clobber it in the nose to fight it off? Not if you plan on getting away. Despite the old saying that aiming for the snout is the best strategy, a shark's most sensitive areas are really its eyes and its gills.
docs.snippet: Punching a shark in the nose is not considered a good way to fight it off.

docs.lead_paragraph: Those cabinets in medical offices stuffed with promotional drug samples may lead doctors to prescribe more expensive drugs, even to patients who cannot afford them, a new study finds. Writing in the current issue of The American Journal of Medicine, researchers say medical residents who have access to the samples are more likely to write prescriptions for heavily advertised drugs than for less expensive brands, generic versions or even over-the-counter medicines.

headline.main: Under the Influence of Drug Samples?

docs.snippet: Access to promotional drug samples may lead doctors to prescribe more expensive drugs, even to patients who cannot afford them, a new study finds.

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Abducted: How People Come to Believe They Were Kidnapped by Aliens,'' by Susan Clancy. Harvard University Press, $22.95. People who have memories of being abducted by aliens become hardened skeptics, of a kind. They dismiss the procession of scientists who explain away the memories as illusions or fantasy. They scoff at talk about hypnosis or the unconscious processing of Hollywood scripts. And they hold their ground amid snickers from a public that thinks that they are daft or psychotic. They are neither, it turns out, and their experiences should be taken as seriously as any strongly held exotic beliefs, according to Susan Clancy, a Harvard psychologist who interviewed dozens of self-described abductees as part of a series of memory studies over the last several years.

headline.main: Explaining Those Vivid Memories of Martian Kidnappers

docs.snippet: A psychologist tries to explain the stories of people who claim to have been abducted by aliens.

docs.lead_paragraph: Are many strokes overlooked simply because they occur on the wrong -- that is to say, the right -- side of the brain? It appears so, according to a study in the journal Lancet.

headline.main: Recognizing Strokes on Each Side of the Brain

docs.snippet: According to a study in the journal Lancet, many strokes that happened on the right side of the brain are being overlooked.
